info.name: Snowflake Task API
info.description:
The Snowflake Task API is a REST API that you can use to access, update, and perform certain actions on task resources in a Snowflake database.

Contact Support:
 Name: Snowflake, Inc.
 Email: support@snowflake.com

item.name: Fetch the dependent tasks of a task

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the schema to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases/{database}/schemas` GET request to get a list of available schemas for the specified database.
(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the resource.

request.description: This operation returns a list of the dependent tasks of the task with identifier {name}.

response.name: successful

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Successfully accepted the request, but it is not completed yet.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Bad Request. The request payload is invalid or malformed. This happens if the application didn't send the correct request payload. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause. The application must reconstruct the r

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Unauthorized. The request is not authorized. This happens if the attached access token is invalid or missing. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause, e.g., expired, invalid token. The application must obtain a

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Forbidden. The request is forbidden. This can also happen if the request is made even if the API is not enabled.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Not Found. The request endpoint is not valid. This happens if the API endpoint does not exist, or if the API is not enabled.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Method Not Allowed. The request method doesn't match the supported API. This happens, for example, if the application calls the API with GET method but the endpoint accepts only POST.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Limit Exceeded. The number of requests hit the rate limit. The application must slow down the frequency of hitting the API endpoints.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Internal Server Error. The server hit an unrecoverable system error. The response body may include the error code and message for further guidance. The application owner may need to reach out the customer support.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Service Unavailable. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

response.name: Gateway Timeout. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.

query.description: Specifies whether to limit the output to include only direct child tasks or to include all recursive child tasks.

item.name: Get the graph runs that are executing or scheduled for the task for the next 8 days.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the schema to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases/{database}/schemas` GET request to get a list of available schemas for the specified database.
(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the resource.

request.description: This function returns details for graph runs that are currently executing or are next scheduled to run within the next 8 days.

response.name: successful
Successfully accepted the request, but it is not completed yet.

Bad Request. The request payload is invalid or malformed. This happens if the application didn't send the correct request payload. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause. The application must reconstruct the r

Unauthorized. The request is not authorized. This happens if the attached access token is invalid or missing. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause, e.g., expired, invalid token. The application must obtain a
Forbidden. The request is forbidden. This can also happen if the request is made even if the API is not enabled.
Not Found. The request endpoint is not valid. This happens if the API endpoint does not exist, or if the API is not enabled.
Method Not Allowed. The request method doesn't match the supported API. This happens, for example, if the application calls the API with GET method but the endpoint accepts only POST.
Limit Exceeded. The number of requests hit the rate limit. The application must slow down the frequency of hitting the API endpoints.

Internal Server Error. The server hit an unrecoverable system error. The response body may include the error code and message for further guidance. The application owner may need to reach out the customer support.
Service Unavailable. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.
Gateway Timeout. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.

item.name: Get the graph runs that are executing or scheduled for the task for the next 8 days.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the schema to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases/{database}/schemas` GET request to get a list of available schemas for the specified database.
(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the resource.

response.name: successful
Successfully accepted the request, but it is not completed yet.

Bad Request. The request payload is invalid or malformed. This happens if the application didn't send the correct request payload. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause. The application must reconstruct the r

Unauthorized. The request is not authorized. This happens if the attached access token is invalid or missing. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause, e.g., expired, invalid token. The application must obtain a
Forbidden. The request is forbidden. This can also happen if the request is made even if the API is not enabled.
Not Found. The request endpoint is not valid. This happens if the API endpoint does not exist, or if the API is not enabled.
Method Not Allowed. The request method doesn't match the supported API. This happens, for example, if the application calls the API with GET method but the endpoint accepts only POST.
Limit Exceeded. The number of requests hit the rate limit. The application must slow down the frequency of hitting the API endpoints.

Internal Server Error. The server hit an unrecoverable system error. The response body may include the error code and message for further guidance. The application owner may need to reach out the customer support.
Service Unavailable. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.
Gateway Timeout. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.

item.name: Get the graph runs that are completed for the task.

query.description: Number of results to return, at most. Default is 1000, valid range is 1 to 10000.
Whether to only return results for tasks runs that have failed. Default is false.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the resource.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the resource.

request.description: Create a (or alter an existing) task. Even if the operation is just an alter, the full property set must be provided.

response.name: Successful request.

query.description:
Query parameter that specifies how to handle the request for a resource that does not exist:
- `true`: The endpoint does not throw an error if the resource does not exist. It returns a 200 success response, but does not take any action on the resource.
- `false`: The endpoint throws an error if the resource doesn't exist.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the schema to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases/{database}/schemas` GET request to get a list of available schemas for the specified database.
(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the resource.

request.description: Delete a task with the task name. If ifExists is used, the operation will succeed even if the object does not exist. Otherwise, there will be a failure if the drop is unsuccessful.

response.name: Successful request.

response.name: Successful request.
Successfully accepted the request, but it is not completed yet.

Bad Request. The request payload is invalid or malformed. This happens if the application didn't send the correct request payload. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause. The application must reconstruct the r

Unauthorized. The request is not authorized. This happens if the attached access token is invalid or missing. The response body may include the error code and message indicating the actual cause, e.g., expired, invalid token. The application must obtain a
Forbidden. The request is forbidden. This can also happen if the request is made even if the API is not enabled.
Not Found. The request endpoint is not valid. This happens if the API endpoint does not exist, or if the API is not enabled.
Method Not Allowed. The request method doesn't match the supported API. This happens, for example, if the application calls the API with GET method but the endpoint accepts only POST.
Limit Exceeded. The number of requests hit the rate limit. The application must slow down the frequency of hitting the API endpoints.

Internal Server Error. The server hit an unrecoverable system error. The response body may include the error code and message for further guidance. The application owner may need to reach out the customer support.
Service Unavailable. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.
Gateway Timeout. The request was not processed due to server side timeouts. The application may retry with backoff. The jittered backoff is recommended.

query.description: Query parameter to filter the command output to return only root resources (resources with no predecessors).
Query parameter to filter the command output by resource name. Uses case-insensitive pattern matching, with support for SQL wildcard characters.
Query parameter to filter the command output based on the string of characters that appear at the beginning of the object name. Uses case-sensitive pattern matching.
Query parameter to limit the maximum number of rows returned by a command.
Query parameter to enable fetching rows only following the first row whose object name matches the specified string. Case-sensitive and does not have to be the full name.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the schema to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases/{database}/schemas` GET request to get a list of available schemas for the specified database.

request.description: Lists tasks under the database and schema, with show options as query parameters.

response.name: successful

Query parameter allowing support for different modes of resource creation. Possible values include:
- `errorIfExists`: Throws an error if you try to create a resource that already exists.
- `orReplace`: Automatically replaces the existing resource with the current one.
- `ifNotExists`: Creates a new resource when an alter is requested for a non-existent resource.

variable.description: (Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the database to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases` GET request to get a list of available databases.

(Required) Identifier (i.e. name) for the schema to which the resource belongs. You can use the `/api/v2/databases/{database}/schemas` GET request to get a list of available schemas for the specified database.

request.description: Create a task, with standard create modifiers as query parameters. See the Task component definition for what is required to be provided in the request body.
